ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A different structure with less pointless busy work and a better teacher would be great.
It should be more organized. Too much of it s simply us freely speaking, and I think at this level of a foreign language we should still focus on more foundational skills like grammar.
There was way too much busy work. The online discussion forum we had to do every week was the stupidest thing I've ever done. It took so much time and was absolutely pointless.
Disorganized, unclear instructions, too many activities, too little feedback

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: A fine German course. The level of its rigor and, subsequently, your level of improvement will vary significantly among sections. Choose wisely.
No, if you don't have to take L4 then don't. It's just not worth it.

You don't learn much more than what you did in L3, would recommend just finishing the textbook yourself and saving yourself the time of attending a class that provides no feedback on countless assignments nor for in-class activities. If you do take the course, expect to invest a lot of time in work that does not receive corrections. Perhaps it was just this professor in particular that preferred to rush from activity to activity without providing comprehensive lessons on them, but I think the structure of the course was partially to blame.
